skill.name: github
skill.description: GitHub CLI - manage repositories, issues, pull requests, actions, releases, and more from the command line.
skill.summary: GitHub CLI - manage repositories, issues, pull requests, actions, releases, and more from the comman...
skill.author: Dicklesworthstone

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation. No executable code, network calls, file system access, or external command execution. The skill provides example commands for the GitHub CLI (gh) which the user must install and execute separately.

content.value_statement: Managing GitHub repositories, issues, and pull requests through the web interface is slow and error-prone. This skill provides comprehensive gh CLI commands for faster workflows directly from your terminal.
actual_capabilities: Authenticate with GitHub using gh auth commands
Create, clone, fork, and view repositories
Manage issues: create, list, view, close, reopen, comment, and assign
Handle pull requests: create, review, merge, and check status
Monitor and manage GitHub Actions workflows and runs
Create, upload, and download releases and gists
limitations: Requires GitHub CLI (gh) to be installed separately on the system
User must have valid GitHub authentication before using most commands
Does not execute commands - only provides command syntax and examples

use_cases.title: Streamlined PR workflow
use_cases.description: Create, review, and merge pull requests without leaving your terminal. Faster than switching to browser.

use_cases.title: CI/CD automation
use_cases.description: Monitor GitHub Actions runs, rerun failed jobs, and trigger workflows manually from command line.

use_cases.title: Repository management
use_cases.description: Manage issues, labels, releases, and secrets across multiple repositories efficiently.

prompt_templates.title: List repository issues
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to list all open issues in a GitHub repository using gh CLI

prompt_templates.title: Create pull request
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I create a pull request from my current branch using gh CLI

prompt_templates.title: Monitor CI/CD runs
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to watch a GitHub Actions run in progress and check if it passed

prompt_templates.title: GitHub API queries
prompt_templates.prompt: How can I use gh api to make GraphQL queries and paginate through results

output_examples.input: Show me how to create a pull request and merge it
output: Create PR from current branch (uses commit messages): gh pr create --fill
View the PR in browser: gh pr view PR_NUMBER --web
Review and approve: gh pr review PR_NUMBER --approve
Merge with squash: gh pr merge PR_NUMBER --squash --delete-branch
Quick check of PR status: gh pr checks PR_NUMBER

best_practices: Install gh CLI from https://cli.github.com before using this skill
Run gh auth login to authenticate before executing any repository commands
Use --web flag to open results in browser when visual interface is preferred
anti_patterns: Typing commands manually without verifying - always ask this skill for correct syntax first
Forgetting to check gh auth status before troubleshooting permission errors
Hardcoding repository names instead of using variables or current directory context

faq.question: How do I install GitHub CLI?
faq.answer: Download from cli.github.com or install via package manager: brew install gh, apt install gh, or choco install gh.

faq.question: What authentication methods does gh support?
faq.answer: gh supports GitHub.com authentication via browser, PAT (personal access token), and SSH key.

faq.question: Can I use gh with GitHub Enterprise Server?
faq.answer: Yes, set GH_HOST environment variable to your enterprise instance hostname for authenticated use.

faq.question: Does this skill execute commands on my system?
faq.answer: No. This skill only provides command examples. You must run gh commands yourself after review.

faq.question: How do I troubleshoot authentication errors?
faq.answer: Run gh auth status to check your authentication state. Use gh auth refresh to refresh tokens.

faq.question: How is this different from using git commands?
faq.answer: git manages local repositories. gh manages operations GitHub cloud like issues, PRs, and actions.
